text: Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)
Solutions and Strategies
Ask students a few general questions to see what they learned from exploring the data about the bank accounts. Students’ comments and questions can lead the discussion.
Suggested Questions

• Do the classes have the same thing happening in their bank accounts? (Answers may be general, such as both accounts are decreasing because the classes are using their money to donate items to the children’s ward. Or answers may be specific, such as Ms. Chang’s class uses more money a week than Mr. Mamer’s.)
  • What do you notice about the amount in the accounts for the two classes? (Students will have various answers that can guide how you proceed with asking other questions in the Summary.)
You may begin by asking a few questions about solutions when an amount is given to have students analyze specific instances in the relationship.

• What If Situation A asks about the amount of money at 10 weeks. We know the value of the x-variable (independent variable). How do we find the value of the other variable? (Various answers using the table, graph, and/or equations.) The basic idea is to see if given the value of x, students can find y.
  • What If Situation A asks about when the money is spent. Where would we see this in the table? (When the amount of money [y-variable or independent variable] is zero.) Where would we see this on the graph? (When the amount of money is zero, the line would hit the x-axis.) You could introduce the vocabulary of x-intercept at this time. But it is not necessary for all students to learn at this time.
  • In What if Situation B, what questions might the student have about the accounts? (In the equation, we know that the amount of money is $100. So the question asked would be: At what time does the account have $100? With the inequality, the question would be: When does the account have less than $100.) The basic idea is to see if given the value of y, can students make sense of finding x.
Making the Mathematics Explicit

This Problem is a chance to make sense of decreasing linear relationships. Question students to bring out all of your previous conversations about how to make sense of linear relationships in various representations, and how to determine if a linear relationship is proportional.
Suggested Questions

• For each class, how much money is being spent or withdrawn each week? (Ms. Chang’s class: $12; Mr. Mamer’s class: $10. For both classes, it isthe constant rate of change or the difference in the amount of money between two consecutive weeks.)
  • Compare the rates of change in this Problem with other rates that we have studied in this Unit. How do the rates in this Problem show up in a table? In a graph? In an equation? (These rates are negative, and the previous rates were positive [or zero]. These tables show a constant decrease in the dependent variable as the independent variable increases. The graphs show lines that decrease from left to right, which is the opposite of the previous rates we studied. The coefficient of the independent variable in these equations is negative, while it was positive in previous Problems.]
  • What are the y-intercepts? Chang: (0, 144) and Mamer: (0, 500)
  • What do they tell you about the money in each class’s account? (How much money is in the account at the start.)
  • What is the pattern of change for the relationship between the variables? (Chang: The amount in the account decreases by $12 each week. Mamer: The amount in the account decreases by $50 every 5 weeks or by $10 each week.)
  • How do we see the pattern of change in the table? (Chang: As the weeks increase by 1, the amount of money in the account subtracts $12. Mamer: As the weeks increase by 5, the amount of money in the account subtracts $50. Or, thinking proportionally, as the weeks increase by 1, the amount of money in the account subtracts $10.)
For Mr. Mamer’s data, some students may need to “zoom into” the table to see the way that the amount changes for every 1 week.

tiles.title: Closely spaced data for Mr. Mamer's class

text: • How do we see the pattern of change in the graph? (The data for both classrooms looks linear because they are taking out a consistent amount each week or set of weeks. The line “falls” or goes down because their monies are decreasing over time. Ms. Chang’s line falls faster because they take out more money each week, which means their rate of change is greater.)

• How can you describe what is happening with each account? (Chang: They start with $144 and they take out $12 every week. Mamer: They start with $500 and they take out $10 every week.)
  • How can we write this as a symbolic expression to represent the pattern in the data for each class? (See below.) How do we know that these expressions are all correct? (At this time, student will use various informal answers using number sense.)
Note that some students may write: 100 – 50x for every 5 weeks
• What is an equation to represent that data from each class?
• How do we see the rate of change in the equation? (The rate of change is the number multiplied by the independent variable or the coefficient of x.)
• How do we see the y-intercept in the equation? (It is the amount that they started with. That amount is added into the equation.)
• Are either of these relationships proportional? (No. Table: We cannot scale values or make proportions. Graph: The line does not go through (0, 0). Equation: There is a non-zero amount added.)
Now What Do Students Know
Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know question.
See answers to the Problem for more information about the strategies and embedded mathematics.
Reflecting on Student Learning
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
• What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know question?

1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?

• How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?
